Specific Details: raise awareness of metastatic breast cancer which is an advanced form of breast cancer where early detection unfortunately does not  improve survival. Even if diagnosed early, 30% of women diagnosed with early breast cancer will progress to metastatic disease. While there have been advances in breast cancer therapy, metastatic breast cancer currently remains incurable and many patients with metastatic breast cancer don't feel part of the the conversation around breast cancer.
DPOs Lobbied: Frances Fitzgerald|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Mary Mitchell O'Connor|Minister|Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation::Colm Burke|Senator|Seanad::Josepha Madigan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: raise awareness of metastatic breast cancer which is an advanced form of breast cancer where early detection unfortunately does not  improve survival. Even if diagnosed early, 30% of women diagnosed with early breast cancer will progress to metastatic disease. While there have been advances in breast cancer therapy, metastatic breast cancer currently remains incurable and many patients with metastatic breast cancer don't feel part of the the conversation around breast cancer.
Intended Results: raise political and public awareness of metastatic breast cancer where scientific progress has not kept pace with early breast cancer and where patients have distinct needs, require better services, and need to feel that their story is recognised in the public discourse about breast cancer.

Specific Details: Requests for PQ information on tobacco control and measures to tackle child vaping
Subject Matter: Requests for PQ information on tobacco control and measures to tackle child vaping
Intended Results:
To secure an update of the estimated annual cost of smoking to the state and if the department of finance will be conducing an updated 2023 report assessing the economic cost of smoking, following on from the 2016 ICF international report ::To determine if the Minister for Health's attention has been drawn to a campaign by an alliance of organisations seeking an increase in the legal age of sale of all forms of tobacco, including e-cigarettes, from 18 to 21 years, commonly known as Tobacco 21 and if he is in favour of Ireland introducing Tobacco 21 as a policy::To secure information on the revenue that would be raised annually if an excise tax of €0.06 per ml of electronic cigarette liquid was applied.::To secure information on the estimated revenue that would be raised annually if an annual €50 electronic cigarette retailer license fee per retail outlet was introduced::To secure information on level of funding provided for tobacco cessation services from 2011 to 2022, and up to date in 2023::To secure PQ information and an update on the current status of the public consultation to ban disposable e-cigarettes and if a timeline has been developed.::To secure information on the number retail outlets registered to sell tobacco on the National Register of Tobacco retailers in 2022 to date in 2023.
::To secure information on the estimated revenue that would be raised annually if an annual €500 tobacco retailer license fee per retail outlet was introduced ::To secure information on level of funding provided for tobacco cessation services from 2011 to 2022, and up to date in 2023::To secure information on the funding provided to Revenue in each year from 2020 to 2023 to combat tobacco smuggling; if Revenue are developing a dedicated anti-smuggling strategy and if the Covid-19 Pandemic has had any impact on Revenue combatting smuggling::To secure information on whether there have been any hospital admissions due to vaping and if there have been any involving under-18s, over the past year.::To secure information from the Minister for Health regarding his awareness of reports from the UK that the popular disposable e-cigarette brand Elf Bar, contained levels of nicotine above the permitted amount, and if the Minister would investigate whether similar breaches of regulation occurred on the Irish Market.::To secure information and clarification that officials in the Department of Finance do not meet with representatives of the Tobacco industry, in adherence to Article 5.3 of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), which Ireland has ratified
